comment: Absolutely not.
It's a competitive slide puzzle. Fuuuuuuuuuck no.
Collectively stare in silence for 5 minutes trying to do a spatial reasoning in your head. Scored 1 only because this defies classification as a game. It's a puzzle.

This is barely a game - excruciatingly boring if you're bad at it like me, and if you're good at it, why play with other people? Might be a good solitaire iOS game for people that like it - go play it by yourself.
No game, puzzle, MPS

Le pongo esta nota porque se me da fatal. Practicamente es como si no jugara, porque cuando todavía estoy mirando los demás ya han encontrado el camino mejor.
Horrible game
It's a puzzle solitaire. Not interesting, I could play a video game in lieu.
mutant meeples is better (acrroding to Tom vasel)
If this is a board game we might as well say that 6 people staring at a Magic Eye puzzle until one of them yells, "I see it! It's a schooner!" is a board game.

Khet for more players but then without the cool lasers. This game is not my cup of tea. For a game to be a game, I expect some laughter, activity, movement, interaction. I also expect there to be a clear goal on how to win. RR has a goal which you need to satisfy in order to win, but human-based heuristics are almost completely useless here. Ricochet Robots is about being entranced in mapping routes on the gameboard in your head in total silence, and then more or less losing interest as a player has found an efficient route which needs to be proven wrong within one minute. This blatant min-maxing is best left to a computer. It's not unlike playing Kakuro or Sudoku Challenge.

If you want a fun and doable puzzle of this kind, I recommend Cities. Just as much puzzling, but at least interactive in the way that something is said from time to time, and that you can actually see what the others are doing.
Blecch.

Not a game, IMHO. I like puzzles as much as the next person. Logic puzzles, cryptograms, Sudoku, etc. But I like to do those things on my iPhone or in the paper to kill time by myself. Doing solo logic puzzles while I pretend I'm playing a game with other people? Not so much.
I flipping hate this game.

I just didn't enjoy this game at all. Everyone just sits in silence staring at the board. Its about as antisocial of a game as I have ever played, which to me defeats the purpose of playing boardgames.

I don't like giving out one's to just any game, but the more I think about it, this really did not feel like a game to me at all. I couldn't recommend this to anyone.
Timed puzzle solving. Blecch.
This is not a game.
Sit on your hands with jaw agape while the one person who's good at the "game" does everything by him or her self. Wheeee!!!
A puzzle game of mind blowing tedium.
I'm not sure what's worse: Ricochet Robot or Roborally. I love some robots (heck, look at my name), but these games are not entertaining for me.
this doesn't qualify as a game, as far as i'm concerned.
Zzzzzzzzzz. Not a game really. A puzzle (if you like puzzles which obviously I don't)
Simplistic.
Sebastien's version

what's fun about a game that punishes newcomers by preventing them to play at all? if you play against somebody who knows the game, all you do is to stare at the board in silence and wait for the game to end. horrible design.
Really not a fan of this game. Might be better if it stopped after someone scores 5 or so.
This is a puzzle, not a game. Stare at the board.
Roborally with the fun removed.
(1999) 1-99 players

Rated this a "1" since, in my opinion, there's no game here, just simultaneous puzzle solving. The only decision one makes is whether or not to "play". From there you all just stare at a board until either someone solves the puzzle or the sweet release of death saves you from more "fun".

This might be ok as a solitaire puzzle (pro tip: there is a free phone app with exactly the same puzzle). As a multiplayer game it's horrible for the following reasons:
* No player interaction whatsoever.
* Less experienced players WILL end up with a total score of 0 and hate the game. I.e. only playable with a group of roughly similar skill level. (The only way to score is to find the best solution in the shortest amount of time among all players. No chance for the new guy in the group.)
* There is no mechanic to influence the game state other than earning score. The players who fall behind might as well stop playing. They can't make any difference.
* Only one game mechanic. Extremely repetitive. Combine this with previous points, and half the players will drop out halfway through.
Sux. I can't even start to rant about this.

2-10 | (4-6) | 30 min | 10+ | Alex Randolph
Good training for developing spacial thinking. In fact, this is a puzzle, a mental challenge, but not a game. It fails to amuse me.
Nem rossz, de sajnos nem sok ember van, akivel játszani tudom. Nem annyira játék, inkább csak feladvány.
Not a game, it's a math puzzle better solved by a computer. Could be a good solitaire game if you are a mathematician.

"Richochet" implies action. Staring at a board for minutes on end is the least action-y thing that I can imagine.

And while it's possible to get better, it's not possible to make the game more fun.

Played 5+ times. Initially I was pleasantly surprised since I had assumed that a "puzzle" board game would be of no interest to me. Once I started playing it, I changed my mind completely...but lately I am reverting to my initial prejudice: I like games, not puzzles posing as games.
Bought at gameskeeper in Oxford

Rating based on one play : April 2014

Might be a great game for puzzle-heads, but I'll never play again. Not my thing at all.

RICOCHET ROBOTS
This might make a good puzzle, but as a boardgame it stinks. Play 'Roborally' instead.

Hated this game. We had a few attempts, but didn't seem to be able to find a middle ground between unbelievably easy and impossibly difficult. I doubt I could ever be persuaded to play it again, although I know some of my friends are fond of it.

Something prompted me to think of this 'game' 6 years after my only play, so I downgraded my rating to remind myself never to play it again.

The game? Every player looks at a picture, then someone says "I can solve this in 5", then everyone gets a minute to make a better bid, then everyone watches the winning bidder to see if they can actually deliver, then everyone does it all over again.
Don't like Science
This is probably an excellent brain exercise, but I just can´t keep track of my programmed robot movements further than a couple of moves. This makes impossible for me to play the game.
Boring, non-social.
not something I ever care to experience again

I like the thought of being better at this game, so I would want to play again as like a brain exercise and strengthener. However, solely for that purpose. Would not be a game I choose to play for fun, so I may not like brain teaser games.

This might be an unfair rating, but it’s a fair warning for folks like me who can’t tell left from right. The special aspect is frustrating and impossible to overcome. But I can see how others enjoy its simple design and challenge to be a quick thinker.

2024-11-16 - 3 - it got very old. I guess it could be more appealing before smartphone era, where we got a lot of similar puzzle games, that are more interesting, more attractive and just better.
What's more - playing Ricochet Robots with more players than 1 seems like a big waste of time.

This is a pure puzzle where the timer is the people you are playing with. It's not a puzzle I enjoy. The fact that others are your timer makes it confrontational in a way that is completely uinteresting. And, I don't even really enjoy watching people's turns as much as I do in other multiplayer solitaire games.

It doesn't help that I think this is a game that I am quite bad at because I am quite poor at calculating solutions. It was very stressful for me to have to balance being the first one to bid a solution while trying to double check my work to ensure I counted correctly.

It does however set up extremely quickly and it is nice that people can drop in and out freely in a party-like setting.
Jeu qui demande une certaine capacité à prédire les moves dans l'espace. Je n'ai pas cette capacité malheureusement ou alors mon cerveau est limité. Pas la patience pour retenter.

This game is probably like my personal torture as far as a game goes. I just don't feel capable of seeing enough steps in my head to be competitive. My friend who owns it enjoys playing it but I think he usually just beats everyone else.

More than 10 games looking at others playing while beeing flabergasted.

This game might be fun. I guess. I see others having fun playing it.
However my very own neural network is underperforming in this kind of tasks, while others in my gaming group are especially gifted. I thus feel, if not discriminated, at least humilated everytime any one of these games hits the table (yes Factory Fun, that's about you as well).
I love "slow" puzzle games (i.e. videogames like lemmings, infernal machines and similar titles) and I love real-time fast games based on visual cues (such as jungle speed, speed, pit, spot it, time'n'space or captain sonar...). But that "thing" is no game for me.
Sulinak megvan
Whole game runs in tense silence. Not fun.
Boring

It's more of a 'me' problem than anything to do with the game itself, but I'm just too bad at this to derive any enjoyment from it. However, I think that does still say something about the design - if you can't think as fast as the other players, then essentially you're just going to be staring at a sand timer for half an hour instead of actually doing anything, and you'll really notice how unnecessarily long it is for such a repetitive experience.
Honestly kind of boring, would be interesting as a solo time burner but otherwise not much point.

This is one of those games where your kids will always beat you because their brains are faster at this sort of thing. I had expected a RoboRally knockoff and got… disappointed.

I got it for almost nothing at a convention, and there's a reason for that. The "gameplay" is really more just staring at a board with your friends for five minutes tracing lines with your eyes and shouting out numbers. Probably good for people who like games based on spatial awareness, puzzles, or proving to their friends how smart they are.

Don't actually own this or have a desire to buy, but i've played it enough to review and i'm willing to play it. Very puzzely game that can make you feel dumb staring at a board with 4 robots on it and not figuring out how to move said robot to a spot. Makes me feel even more dumb when someone figures out an optimal path that i cannot see. I wouldn't say i'm terrible or good at this game, and for me to play i need others on my level. Someone dominating this game can break it IMO. That said i see the genius of the design and this is the sort of game that has very little middle appeal. You either love puzzles and programmable movement or it's a convoluted mess and want no part.
I don't like speed test game like this.
Requires the memorization of complicated moves - which is beyond me. Great for people who can memorize huge sequences of moves, I guess.
I guess I can see how competitive puzzle-solving could be construed as a game, but it doesn't feel like a game to me, just a tedious exercise.

Ugh. Maybe as a puzzle for playing solo. Ultimately, finding shortest routes is a skill that you can train, and the game is then just showing off your skill.

Just not my kind of game. It really only works if everyone playing is of the same skill level. Otherwise the better players will be the only ones that have any fun, and the others will just be frustrated.

TRADED

Like many other staring games (e.g. Set) a person can be simply better at the underlying task in a way that the gameplay won't interfere with. So it's sort of mental arm-wrestling: who's the best at this thing?

You might ask, aren't all games like that in some way? I guess yes. There's just a particular feel that they have when it's so stark, and when the footing each player plays from at a given moment is necessarily unvaried -- we're all trying to solve the same puzzle, I don't have any different a task than you do at this moment.

Which I guess brings me to the fact that I don't enjoy this particular task, and maybe that's my real beef with it.

[5 plays]

In fact, in a three-player game with me, a construction manager, against two computer geeks I went on a five turn winning streak and won with 7 shortest routes, or whatever they are called. Wonderful game to play when drunk or with large groups, it's a simple idea that's well executed, but can get boring after a while.

Pros:
The puzzle is plain fun and solving it competitively genuinely works because there's usually a simple solution that someone fast can find and a more advanced solution that's better that needs to be found under time-pressure.

Cons:
This game gets less fun the better you get at it, especially when playing with new players. As I've played it a few times and are generally good at these types of puzzles, I don't really want to play this more.

Elegant rules for generating and competitively solving computer-game-feeling puzzles from cardboard. But there's too much short-term memory strain for too little enjoyment, for me. Would be fine as a record-your-move videogame.
This is completely not my type of game at all. Does not feel like a game. Fastest brain wins.
The type of game that you need to play lots of time to get good at it. Unfortunately, I have no interest in playing it in the first place.
This feels like players are competitively and concurrently calculating Djikstra's algorithm or A* in their head. Not my idea of recreational computing.

Not for the mathematically, dimensionally & spatially challenged. Cold hard logic really, not really a game as such, but played every 4 or 5 years & it won't wear out its welcome.

Strangely though, I would encourage kids to "play" this, it would help develop systematic thinking.

Utterly fails as a game because the same player will win 100% of the time.

I enjoy it as a brief diversion, but that is all.

Get together, stare at the board, figure out as many as 20+ moves in their head, until someone declares Bonanza! or somesuch, demonstrates their efficient route, then... everyone starts all over again? Wow. That's some tepid gaming sessions I'm missing.

This works fine with one player. I have to say, though, it is not so much a game as it is a puzzle. I guess a competitive puzzle is a game.

A competitive puzzle... even though there are enough elements to classify it as a game in the BGG taxmonomy, it still feels like a puzzle, or an exam question on a standardized test, meant to weed out the brightest of the 1st percentile from the 2nd percentile of MIT math and physics nobel-prize winners.... not for the feeble-minded like myself. Or three other hard-core gamers who tried it out tonight. Yuck, we all said, please let us play something else.

I took this game out and studied it a little and found it a puzzle of sorts. It is interesting to see how many moves you can dwindle it down too. I may get around to playing it one fine day. On the other hand, I don't know. I'm not really sure I like this kind of game.
I simply do not enjoy this in any way.

Ricochet Robots is a fine game I will play here and there. It's essentially a series of puzzles and whomever solves them the fastest wins. Which is quite fine for some fun here and there but just doesn't get me super excited or pumped to play. Overall it's rarely the sort of experience I am looking for while gaming.

For people who are a fan of figuring the least number of turns optimization puzzle for a robot to go from one spot to another (which is the entire game here), and want to do it faster than others rather than having an app that tells you the absolute minimum number of turns and can create more varied maps, this is a fine game. For people who suck at it like me, this game is really frustrating as you end up being able to do nothing. Enjoyability of playing is about a 3 for me, but I also appreciate its design so hence the 5.
More of a randomly setup puzzle than a game with very limited player interaction. It certainly sets aside the logical thinkers of the group. I always want to play Robo Rally instead.
Fun puzzle. Not really a game.

My thoughts:
An intense mini thinking game that is also fun! I enjoyed this game the first time I played it Jan '08 at Jenn's house, because it wasn't what I expected (not like robo rally at all).

Now this is a great coffee game if you have the right group of people! Maybe if I play it more I see patterns repeat too much but I doubt I'll get to that point so. A real treat of a puzzle, not so much of a game but who cares when it delivers a great time! Speed puzzle solving. So, really, just an IQ test. If you're good at that sort of thing, you'll love it. Otherwise, you'll hate it. Thus, no broad appeal and the low-ish score I give it.

Matt's mods:
- Note the BGG FAQ about single-move solutions not being allowed:

> Immediately returning a robot back in the opposite direction it has just travelled from is an illegal move; "...it may move back the way it came only after another robot moves." (source: RGG 2nd edition rules)
> An active robot (the robot that currently corresponds to the target space) must ricochet ("turn right or left") off an obstacle at least once before it is even allowed to reach the target space. (In other words, if it could reach the target space without ricocheting, another route must be chosen).
> So, finishing a set-up in one straight move is not allowed. Neither is it legal to move the active robot in the opposite direction only to return it to the target space after moving another robot; while these moves would be legal in themselves, the solution would be illegal as the active robot would not have ricocheted on the way to the target space.

It's a nice attempt at trying to prevent them... but not complete. It assumes it can only happen from an open space. Thus, it could be better to say that you must always come in from the direction other than the single-move direction (that is, assuming destination spaces always have 2 walls next to them--I haven't looked at the game enough to know).

- In addition to the above, consider banning anything with 3 moves or less with only the active bot (throw it back in the pot and select a new target--if not the last target, that is--otherwise... see first bullet, I suppose, and it is what it is).

- If you are talented at this game and playing with new players, don't be the first to announce a solution. Hold off on that until the other players are up to speed.

- To add an element of luck to broaden the appeal of the game... the best I have so far is for each player to choose a color they cannot move (not silver/black). This adds 10-20% luck (still far short of the 40-60% that is preferred by most). Then, when it is "your color's" turn to move, you have two rule options: (easier) skip that turn, or (harder to adapt to) you are allowed to move all colors. I suggest the former--skip that turn.

Imagine going on a work assignment to a faraway country where you don’t speak the language. Your local contact has decent English (thank goodness) and you get the project off to a great start.
At the end of the day he mentions that he’s hosting a board game night at his place and asks if you want to join. Why not, you say. It’s not like you’ve much else going on.
When you arrive at game night, you’re greeted by an enthusiastic group of 10 locals. They are just about to start a game of Codenames - amazing, a game you already know!
As soon as they set up, you realize that there is a problem: this is a localized version and you can’t even begin to decipher any of the words. What’s worse is that none of the guests seem to have any interest in speaking English so for a good 90 minutes you just sit and watch them yell at each other and have a riot while you try your very best to pretend that you understand what is going on.

That’s what playing this game feels like to me. My brain can’t do it. Must be fun though… 6/10 for the unique concept.
Sold

About Ricochet Robots:

1) What is it?
I admit: I once, and until a few time ago, thought Ricochet Robots was a dexterity game in which players needed to flick the bots in order to hit others to order to take them out of the board or to a given place. I truly did. Now I know how wrong I was. Because Ricochet Robots only uses the dexterity of the mind, in a very puzzle-y type of game.

There is no luck in Ricochet Robots, just thought - hard, continuous path-making, number counting, 1000 brain-rpms. A good computer program will probably crush you, so if you are those that don't like games were computers are simply better, well, skip this one.

Ricochet Robots is a game for those looking to challenge their spatial awareness, coupled with the time pressure of beating the others to the answer - but it doesn't have to be the "correct" one, just the smallest one anyone could find.

2) How do you play?
The round starts when a token is revealed and put in the center of the board. The token says the color of the bot that must be moved and also the place to take it. The goal of each round is to take a given bot to a required place on the board in as few movements as possible, considering the bots always move until they hit a wall or another bot. Other bots can be moved also, even if, say, the goal is to lead the green bot, you can move the red and blue, to allow the green to reach its proper place. The person that calls for the smallest number and actually delivers the bot correctly in that number, takes the token.

The bots moved stay in the place they finish. Then another round starts.

The winner will be the person with the most tokens when all of them were taken.

3) Which are the decisions made during play?
Where to move the bot and if moving the other bots will help (most of the time, it does). Do this as fast as possible.

4) What are the good things in the game?
- Nice production value - the tiles and tokens are OK and the bots are neat;
- Straightforward gameplay - small set of rules, easy to teach and to play, with no exceptions to the main rules;
- No luck;
- Can work both as a game for game night, or as a teaching tool.

5) Which are the bad news?
- Playing time is short, but can be extend due to lots of thinking;
- Can be frustrating (more on that bellow);
- With the no luck element, different skills will normally provide the same end result.

6) How do you feel while playing?
Like you are in a math contest, doing equations. The chalk hits the blackboard with fury, as you try to do the calculations faster than your opponents. You can't say if they are ahead of you or not. The tension is high. You finish first, yelling to the jury: "Fourteen!" You notice you are the first to speak and are beaming with joy. Then someone else says: "Twelve." You freeze. The jury rises, walks to you both, slowly. Then she extends her hand, to shake the hand of your opponent.

For the most part in a play of Ricochet Robots you will be staring at the board, in deep silence, making additions and paths in your head, trying to figure out the best way to lead a bot to its required place. Then this can turn into three possible scenarios:
a) elation: you said a number no one else could lower, and you actually were able to meet what you said and get the token;
b) frustration: you are still crawling your way to the proper place for the bot, when someone else says: "Twelve!". Wait, what? Twelve?! You are still in the "three" and leagues away from the point you want to take the bot to. You then stare at the board, dumbfounded, trying to come up with a miracle, but the added pressure of the timer only helps to make you have even more difficulty to do the task. You accept your destiny and just let it be, frustrated;
c) elation to frustration: you said a number, the lowest one, that you simply couldn't fulfill, due to a mistake. You are ashame and frustrated with yourself.

I get similar feelings with Ubongo and its brothers - and this is why I usually avoid playing them. Not that other type of games don't have these feelings also: when a long-planned strategy fails due to a wrong action/move, I also get frustrated, and when it works, it rocks. However, the frustration usually only happens once, while in Ubongo is an exercize in how much of it can i handle in 45 minutes.

Ricochet Robots allows for some great quiet times, and works really well to develop spatial inteligence - a friend of mine used it in a teaching program used in several schools, with big success: it was amazing to see a whole class of loud-mouths kids and teens stop and be silent while trying to finish the puzzle.

Overall, Ricochet Robots isn't a game I'm keen on revisiting, but this is due to my shortcomings and preferences than about the game itself, as it works perfectly for its intend purposes, being smart, clean and challenging. It can truly be a total winner for you, in more than one way.
A satisfying spatial puzzle, though I can't see this working well as a social experience.

本遊戲是在競爭環境下，每人抽象思考如何讓機器人使用最少步數走到標記，機器人每一步都只能走到碰壁才能轉彎，最先想到走法的人可以喊出步數，然後倒轉沙漏，其他玩家則須趕在沙漏滴完前想出更少的步數，不然就得棄權，最終由想出步數最少的玩家來執行操作。本遊戲非常困難，其實不太適合幼兒，因為就連成人玩就覺得很有挑戰度，光是要在腦中抽象的模擬步數就非常燒腦，還要在競爭及時間限制下完成，需要運用非常多的抽象思考能力和記憶力，兒童的認知和智力發展未成熟，要參與這樣的遊戲確實比較吃力，可能需要配合兒童簡化規則或降低難度，才比較適合。

For Multiplayer: RR is a very interesting puzzle / activity. No matter how many times I play this game, I always enjoying my time with it. Moreover, even if it's a 1999 game, it proves that something can be so simple, yet so engaging, Elegant and fun at times.

There are two downsides that should be considered first though. The first one is that you HAVE to "test" this game in a boardsgame cafe, where there are high chances you will find it. Test it with you gaming buddy (-ies), the people you are playing the most. You HAVE to see whether you all are liking it, because it's one of those games where you either like it or hate it. That's something understandable since it's a puzzle where specific parts of your brain are engaging in solving the visual routing/mapping challenges. Some people are not good at it and they will not like it, so before buying, make sure you play it somewhere else.

The 2nd downside is IMO the high price of it. You see a lot of games are being released nowdays with many components, new ideas etc. etc which are cheaper than this. Here in my country, this is usually priced at €40 - €45, which is kind of a bummer, since there are so many games out there with much more componets and a better price, ultimately making RR not a VFM game.

For Solo: If you play this as a solo, then you open the chips and try to find the solution until the timer runs out. I played this ~ 5 times (including the maps with the coloured barriers) and I won easily most of them. Whether its mebeing good at these puzzles or this game being easy once you get the hang of it, I wouldn't suggest it as a primary solo game, except if you like such puzzles so much, while you are not so good at them, therefore you want something that may challenge you, finding it as a mental practice as well.

I admire the clever design, but find it a bit dry.

Possible improvements:

1) Every time you win, your handicap increases by 1 (i.e. with handicap added to all your future solution scores). This helps balance the game for players of different skills (e.g. if play to 10 points, highly unlikely one player can keep winning; the weaker ones should be able to grab at least a few points, and personal progress can be measured by reducing the handicap gap).

2) The solution length could be computed as the maximum movement of any single robot (rather than summed movement of all robots). This leads to more interesting solution possibilities, since it incentivizes more robots to move. (When I play online, optimal solution is usually 1 or 2 robots moving; but 3+ moving is more interesting imo.)

As a fan of puzzly games, this one hits the right spot. Just one simple mechanic, try to position the robots in such a way that the colored robot reaches its colored token space. This is a classic one for me and you can pull it out very quickly for a couple of rounds. And for people who do not like this, take its concept as it is, it's a thinky puzzly game, do not expect hilarious interaction and dice and gigantic mini's and hidden traitors etc., just puzzle away :-).

As to the remarks of the non-fans that the best player always takes the win, that's not necessarily true. The timer makes sure of that.

If AI would play this game, you would completely be destroyed by it :-D.

5th Play Thoughts  8  (Feb 2023):

Ricochet Robots is a melt your brain puzzle game that is very fun for me, but not for everyone. The puzzle of the game and trying to beat other players is very fun and satisfying, but some players can feel dumb if they can't figure it out round after round. I really enjoy that you can play the game with any number of people, and the table is dead silent until someone shouts out a random number, then it is 30 seconds of frantic calculating in your head. It is also really fun to see at the end of the round the different paths you take vs your opponents. Love breaking this game out to work my brain.

A brilliant abstract puzzle-generator game with more than one solution—but some solutions are better than others. It can accommodate a big group, but I also like to play it solo.

Ricochet Robots is a quirky logic puzzle that somehow, someway works phenomenally as a game. Although turns are taken entirely in the player's minds, there's a lot of tension and enjoyment as everyone around the table scrambles to figure out the solution. We've opted to having this set up as people arrive for game day, jumping in when they can, and in those situations Ricochet Robots shines marvelously.
Simple, clever, masterfully designed, and offering a unique (and silent) playing experience.

Excellent game, really attractive to people when they see it and always more challenging than expected.

I found this game very frustrating and not fun; that is, until I found the two-player turn-based variant on the Geek. It completely changes the game to a very tense, fast, race game where one is trying to get all of their colored chits first.

With the original rules I give it a 7, with this variant it is hovers between a 9 and a 10.

Check it out, especially if the game has lost its appeal for you. Its a totally different and, IMHO, much better game.

This is a tricky game to rank, because it's the sort that comes to the table now and then and could be overplayed if you're not careful, but when it comes out the right amount it's terrific. Also the fact that you can play for as long as you like, jump in and out, etc. and it really makes you use your brain is great. This is one of those games I doubt we'd ever get rid of; it always has a place on our shelf.

Perhaps one of the greatest thinky fillers out there and one that continually finds its place at my table.

I love this game. I used to play it back in 2004 when I was a university student, in a nice place with a long-lost friend of mine. He moved to another country, and playing this game always brings back those memories.

A few years ago, around 2–3 years back, I bought it again. I still enjoy it just as much as I did then. I like it as much as chess, maybe even more.

What I really appreciate is that in this game, the only thing you rely on is your own thinking. Of course, chess requires deep thinking too, but at higher levels, players often depend heavily on memorized openings and famous combinations rather than pure creativity.

With this game, there are no shortcuts or ways to cut corners—you simply have to focus and think. That’s what makes it truly special!

Ricochet Robots rewards players for being good at one thing. It's an understandably polarizing game. Solving a puzzle in one's head doesn't sound like it should be fun. However, with the right group, Ricochet Robots allows players to mesmerize others with creative solutions.

Sometimes, players abandon their competitive nature and work together to solve a challenging puzzle.

And all of this is before introducing the silver robot, to create your own variants!

Brilliant. I can feel my brain shifting to a fundamentally different form of problem solving.
